question.text: In the structure of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>SF</mi><mn>4</mn></msub></math>, the lone pair of electrons on <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi></math> is in.

options.text: Equatorial position and there are two lone pair - bond pair repulsions at <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>90</mn><mo>°</mo></math>.
equatorial position and there are three lone pair - bond pair repulsions at <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>90</mn><mo>°</mo></math>.
axial position and there are three lone pair - bond pair repulsion at <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>90</mn><mo>°</mo></math>.
axial position and there are two lone pair - bond pair repulsion at <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>90</mn><mo>°</mo></math>.

solution.text:
In SF4, The lone pair is in an equatorial position, and there are two lp—bp repulsions. Hence, the following arrangement shown below is more stable.

The shape shown in the following figure is described as a distorted tetrahedron, a folded square or a see-saw.
